Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel Support for 2019 ACM Special Interest Group on Management of Data (ACM SIGMOD)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award enables about 16 US students to participate in the 2019 Association of Computing Machinery International Conference on Management of Data (SIGMOD-2019) held in Amsterdam, Netherlands, June 30 - July 5, 2019. The aim is to support a diverse group of students, including students from under-represented groups and make it possible for them to attend the conference and discuss and disseminate their work. The conference also provides an opportunity for them to interact with future national and international scientific collaborators. The students will gain important training in data management research and this will contribute to the development of a new generation of researchers, educator and practitioners.

The SIGMOD conference, which was established in 1975, has a dynamic and comprehensive program for publication, education, and interaction, including research papers, tutorials, panels, industrial papers, technical demonstrations, and undergraduate research papers. The program includes publications relating to all aspects of data management defined broadly, and particularly encourages publications on topics of emerging interest in the research and development communities. The program also includes workshops that demand dedicated coverage due to their relevance to the current data management research and development, industrial exhibits, and keynote talks by leaders in academia and industry. All these activities provide a unique opportunity for students to share their knowledge, experience, and research work with internationally recognized researchers from both academia and industry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
ACM SIGMOD 2019 was held in Amsterdam, Netherlands. The conference included a dynamic and comprehensive program, including research papers, tutorials, panels, industrial papers, technical demonstrations, undergraduate research papers. The program also included workshops that demand dedicated coverage due to their relevance to the current data management research and development, industrial exhibits, and keynote talks by leaders in academia and industry.

In addition to meeting industry (such as IBM, Microsoft, Oracle, SAP, NEC, HP, Google, Intel, Yahoo!) leaders during regular program sessions, this year students also actively participated in New Researcher Symposium and the ACM Student Research Competition.

A PC reviewed the initial abstract submissions and invite selected students to attend SIGMOD 2019 to present a poster. A panel of judges reviewed the posters and selected students to give a research talk on the next day where the final winners were determined. Three winners from each category were recognized in the conference and will receive prizes. Moreover, the grand winner from each category advanced to an ACM-wide competition.

SIGMOD 2019 had 1063 registrants, out of which 321 were from the US. In total, there were 46 countries represented at SIGMOD 2019, some of which include: Algeria, Australia, Austria, Belgium, Brazil, Canada, Chile, China, Comoros, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Gambia, Germany, Greece, Guinea, Hong Kong, Hungary, India, Ireland, Israel, Italy, Japan, Korea, Republic of, Luxembourg, Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Poland, Qatar, Russian Federation, Saudi Arabia, Senegal, Serbia, Singapore, South Africa, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey, United Arab Emirates, United Kingdom, United States.

The search committee included 3 members (Qiong Luo from Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, Nan Tang from Qatar Computing Research Institute, and Parth Nagarkar from New Mexico State University) to review application materials (that included student research summary and rationale explaining the expected benefits for the applicants).

The NSF grant was used to provide varying degrees of support, where the maximum awarded amount was $1620, to 12 students matriculated in US institutions and who have actively participated in the conference through presentations, technical demonstrations, and other direct contributions to the SIGMOD program.  The broad impacts included training and development of the future generation of leaders and workforce in the increasingly critical field of data management. Awardees were given priority access to on-site and off-line educational and mentorship events.

Here are a few comments from students who have received NSF support for attending the conference:

* “It helped to attend the SIGMOD '19. And by attending, I gained a lot experience, networking, and new ideas for my research.”

* “This travel award significantly reduced the financial pressure on our side. It helped offset the flight tickets expense. We really appreciate it!”

* “I had a first author publication with an external collaborator. My advisor could not directly fund my travel since they were not involved in the project, and my external collaborators did not have a provision to fund me. So the travel award helped me greatly in attending the conference, talking to various interested academics and practitioners. That helped me understand how my technical contribution fits well within the larger context.”
